etymology.description: 刀(刀) (dāo, "knife") + 口(口) (kǒu, "mouth") = call out with one's mouth -> summon
etymology.interpretation: Originally depicted hands over a wine vessel, symbolizing hospitality or serving wine, illustrating summoning guests. Later evolved to include 口(口) to emphasize calling out or summoning orally, while 刀(刀) serves as a phonetic marker.

examples.chinese: 国王召集忠诚的骑士(國王召集忠誠的騎士)，前往讨论国事(前往討論國事)。
examples.pinyin: guówáng zhàojí zhōngchéng de qíshì, qiánwǎng tǎolùn guóshì.
examples.english: The king summons loyal knights, heading off to discuss state affairs.

examples.chinese: 校长召见家长(校長召見家長)，讨论学生表现(討論學生表現)。
examples.pinyin: xiàozhǎng zhàojiàn jiāzhǎng, tǎolùn xuéshēng biǎoxiàn.
examples.english: The principal summons the parents to discuss the students' performance.
